subject: Re: [junit] Proposed parameterized test syntax for JUnit 4
msgSnippet: ... Part of the issue is that when writing individual tests the method name, which is required, documents the test. Yes you can write test1, test2, test3, etc.
messageBody:
David Saff wrote:
> Elliotte Harold wrote:
>
>> David Saff wrote:
>>
>>> What do you think of J. B. Rainsberger's suggestion of adding a test
>>> name to each set of parameters? Would that address these concerns?
>> It helps in part. However it relies too much on programmer design for my
>> comfort. This could become very obscure and opaque very quickly.
>
> Can you expand on "relies too much on programmer design"? I think I
> might know what you mean, but best to make sure.


Part of the issue is that when writing individual tests the method name,
which is required, documents the test. Yes you can write test1, test2,
test3, etc. but most programmers don't and when they do they feel itchy
about it and eventually go back to fix it. It's an obvious smell.

The proposed parameterized test syntax is more like an assert method
that may or may not have a message. Asserts without messages don't smell
as bad, and aren't as likely to get fixed. Probably they don't need to
be when the test method name documents the problem, as do the expected
and actual values. However with the parameterized test annotations we
lose the method name but don't necessarily get anything to
counterbalance it.
